results.title: Narritjin Maymuru (A)
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, Ian Dunlop and Philip Robertson
results.brief_description: Narritjin Maymuru is a respected aboriginal artist. This series of films profiles the man and his work, as well as looking at the traditional way of life he and his family follow at Djarrakpi near Yirrkala in the Northern Territory. Photography is by Dean Semler.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Film Australia, Ian Dunlop and Philip Robertson

results.title: Narritjin in Canberra
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
The film shows Narritjin and Banapana and their families at work in their ANU studio and later an exhibition of their work. In 1978 Narritjin Maymuru and his son Banapana were awarded fellowships as Visiting Artists to the Faculty of Arts at the Australian National University in Canberra. This program shows Narritjin and Banapana and their families at work in their A.N.U. studio. With anthropologist Howard Morphy, Narritjin conducts a seminar session for anthropology students. He explains his technique of bark painting and discusses some of the meanings behind the paintings. At the end of their stay in Canberra, Narritjin and Banapana hold an exhibition of their Manggalili art.

results.title: Narritjin at Djarrakpi. Part 2 (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
This program continues the life of Narritjin and his family at his clan settlement at Djarrakpi. Throughout Narritjin tells of his feelings about Djarrakpi and of his hopes for the future. A continuation of the study of the life of Narritjin and his family at his clan settlement at Djarrakpi, where they live largely off the land and the sea, producing bark paintings and craftwork to sell at Yirrkala. Gives an insight into Narritjin’s family life and his role as an educator to his sons.

results.title: Narritjin at Djarrakpi. Part 1 (A)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Narritjin Maymuru (A)”.
Narritjin Maymuru and his family are establishing a small settlement at Djarrakpi, an important Manggalili clan site on the northern head of Blue Mud Bay in the Northern Territory. Narritjin is a renowned artist and he and his family produce bark paintings and craft work to sell at Yirrkala. This program, together with Part 2 [507335], gives an insight into Narritjin’s family life and, through his paintings, his role as an educator, teaching his sons about their clan land and its ancestral history.

results.title: Nargun
results.creator_credit: Australian Broadcasting Commission and John Walker
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Nargun and the stars”.
Based on Patricia Wrightson’s novel of the same name, this is the story of Simon Brent, a city boy who comes to live with his country relatives after the death of his parents. In this episode Simon must finally face the menacing giant rock, The Nargun.

results.title: Narcotics: why not?
results.brief_description: Sixteen residents of the California Rehabilitation Centre relate how they were introduced to pills, glue, marijuana, and heroin - what it was like and the hopes they hold for the future. These former addicts give telling extemporaneous statements as to what traffic in drugs and narcotics means.

results.title: Narcotics: the decision (D)
results.creator_credit: United Research and Training Production and Robert W Larsen
results.brief_description: Shows how a teenage girl seeking the adult world turns to cigarettes and liquor. She is then introduced to marijuana, tries heroin, and suddenly is surrounded by a network of smugglers and drug pedlars. Shows how drugs are injected and the excruciating pain addicts suffer when unable to get a “fix”. Please Note This film is not suitable for screening to children under fifteen. It is suggested the film be previewed for suitability to the proposed audience before screening. Warning: SOME SCENES MAY DISTURB.

results.title: Narcotics file: the victims
results.creator_credit: United Nations Television, Journal Films and Pierre Desbonnet
results.brief_description: Examines the various treatment programs being attempted throughout the world, admitting with reluctance that as yet there is no cure for heroin addiction. Shows drug-free communes, methadone maintenance, heroin maintenance, harsh jail sentences, one-to-one psychological treatment and prison-treatment centres.

results.title: Narcotics file: the source
results.creator_credit: United Nations Television, Journal Films and Pierre Desbonnet
results.brief_description: Deals with Thailand’s part in the “Golden Triangle” which originates about half the world’s illicit opium supply. Here a joint UN-Thai Government project is attempting to provide alternative cash crops for the hill tribes who earn what little money they have from the cultivation of the opium poppy.

results.title: Nara: a stroll through history
results.creator_credit: Shu Taguchi Productions and Shin Nippon
results.brief_description: The first of Japan’s capitals built in the middle of the sixth century, Nara is one of the country’s most ancient cities. It is a great temple with broad avenues and many fine buildings. The capital was moved to Kyoto, but Nara is still known as the “cradle of Japanese culture”.
